Orthogonality properties of sinusoids

As stated earlier, a periodic function \(f(t)\) with period \(2\pi\) has a Fourier series representation \[ \begin{align} f(t) &= \dfrac{a_0}{2} + a_1 \cos t + a_2 cos 2t + \dots + b_1 \sin t + b_2 \sin 2t + \dots , \\ &= \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum _{n=1}^\infty \left( a_n \cos nt + b_n \sin nt \right) \end{align} \] To determine the Fourier coefficients \(a_n\), \(b_n\) and the constant term \( \dfrac{a0}{2} \) use has to be made of certain integrals involving sinusoids, the integrals being over a range \( \alpha \), \( \alpha+2\pi\), where \(\alpha\) is any number. (We will normally choose \( \alpha = -\pi\).)
